item.title: jonny (good kind)
item.description:
@computingnature
The "simplify installation" one aka "package your code" is so huge. The number of projects I come across that are simply unpackaged or just have a plaintext list of deps and are otherwise a loose bundle of MATLAB or python files are always unfortunate, because they rarely survive longer than the paper announcement. Thinking about how I spent a day repackaging moseq bc someone in our lab was curious about it but couldnt install, and then never got a reply in the issue

item.title: jonny (good kind)
item.description:
@computingnature
These cover a lot of common problems I have with scientific code, one minor one to add is "build more, smaller things" - splitting up a very large monolithic code base into several smaller pieces can work with all the above tips to make the software much more useful over time. Being able to re-use pieces between projects without needing to make future projects direct dependents of humongous prior packages is a huge deal for labs that might make many tools.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: They tried really hard but failed to get the slightest useful information from NIH and universities.I think it's fair to say that the institutions are just staring at headlights at the moment. Their procedures are great for slow burials, less so for reacting quickly, robustly and publicly.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Various quotes express sympathy and concern for Masliah's coworkers. Yes, he's very likely to end up the villain of the piece. But, harsh as it may sound, they share some responsibility and at least have a duty of candour now. We should be careful not to treat the coworkers better than their colleagues and competitors who neither let misconduct slide nor benefited from it.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Systemic reform is obviously required (but don't hold your breath) given the scale of the case and the numbers of people involved without a single whistleblower account reaching the surface.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Scientists were "...deeply concerned for the reputation of scientific investigation in their field."Sorry, but that's backwards. They should be concerned about the quality of the research in their field. It reminds me of the obsession with "confidence in the markets" at the expense of the economic fundamentals.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: This is a case of shooting the messenger. What's not fair is that journals and institutions did not get their act together much sooner.Moreover, all the commentary that's been made public has been quite careful about not jumping to conclusions. The problem is just that some of the issues are self-evidently terrible: no right-minded scientist can unsee the issue or conceive of an innocent explanation...And, of course, the initial manipulations were also unfair.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: I should add that I expect some coworkers to be genuinely blameless. The situation where one experiment was outsourced to Masliah's group would be one where it would be easy to be fooled. Although one might hope that, over time, any problems of reproducibility or consistency with other results might reveal themselves and be acknowledged.
